black stories - Das Spiel Wer durch Grips und Glück die meisten Blutchips sammelt, wird das schwarze Genie und gewinnt black stories - Das Spiel! Rabenschwarze black stories, Gebieter mit morbider Gesinnung und ein nach Blut dürstendes Ratevolk erwarten euch. Es wimmelt von Mördern, Blut und Leichen ... so wie ihr es von black stories kennt! Aber dieses Mal muss der starke Gebieter dem Ratevolk nicht nur durch Fragen und Antworten auf die Sprünge helfen, sondern auch durch Sketche und Pantomime. Seine Entscheide sind unumstößlich, auch wenn sich das Ratevolk vor ihm im Staube wälzt. Der beste Tüft ler erhält vom gnädigen Gebieter lebenserhaltende Blutchips. Doch was passiert, wenn ein Spieler plötzlich im Gefängnis landet oder ihm der Lebenssaft ausgeht? Oder er beim Vampirwettspiel vernichtet wird? Das Messer wird entscheiden .. und frisches Blut wird fließen ... Seid bereit für den rabenschwarzen Rätsel-, Action- und Mordsspaß!
• 80 brandneue morbide black stories • erweiterbar mit allen black stories-Kartensets

boardgame.name: Dipole Chess
Forwards Chess
boardgame.description:
This game is a cross between regular chess and Mark Steere's Dipole. The game is won by either capture your opponent's King instead of checkmating, or by having your opponent not be able to move any pieces. This is done by restricting non-capture movement to only moving forward (straight or diagonally), rather than laterally or backwards. Castling remains the same as in normal chess, and pieces may capture as the do normally, including laterally or backwards.

This small change in the results results in a game that last only a finite number of turns, and with one side guaranteed a win. Even though the game is more restrictive in some regards over normal chess, it is still a deep game. Due to the game being a cross between Dipole and normal chess, it bears the name Dipole Chess. Fans of chess and Dipole should consider checking this game out.

The latest version of the game rules for Dipole Chess can be found here:
http://www.chessvariants.org/index/msdisplay.php?itemid=MSdi...

A Zillions adaptation of the game can be found here:
http://www.zillionsofgames.com/cgi-bin/zilligames/submission...;id=1617

boardgame.name: Orzeł Morski 1939-45
Sea Eagle 1939-45
boardgame.description:
Tactical game about naval battles in WWII. Quite detailed (different armaments, armours, areas of hit and so on) but easy and fast to play.

Game scale:
1 hex = 1km
1 game turn = 5 minutes
1 counter = 1 big ship or group of smaller ones

Contains 7 scenarios:
* Battle in Danzig (Gdańsk) Bay at 01. 09. 1939 (hypothetical - Poland vs Soviet Union)
* Operation Albion II at 22. 06. 1941 (hypothetical - Germany vs. Soviet Union)
* Battle of Cape Matapan 28-29. 03. 1941 (historical - England vs Italy)
* Battle of the Komandorski Islands, 26. 03. 1943 (historical - USA vs Japan)
* Operation VADO 15. 06. 1940 (hypothetical - France vs Italy)
* Battle of Empress Augusta Bay, 02. 11. 1943 (historical - USA vs Japan)
* 2nd battle of Samar Island 25. 11. 1944 (hypothetical - USA vs Japan)

boardgame.name: ECOnomia
boardgame.description:
ECOnomia is a game where each player is the CEO of a major corporation and throughout the turns they must add companies to their holdings by buying them, increasing their economic power.
The problem is that on times of growing pollution levels, and the sustainability of our planet at stake, the CEOs must show their alignment with the preservation tendencies, sustainability measures and social responsibility. As so they must meet the emission levels set by the government, paying higher taxes for higher emission levels with caution not to exceed the limit established. The winner of this game is the CEO who manages to get the most "Green Points" (victory points) by choosing carefully the companies they bought, by cleaning their plants with the usage of technologies and by doing environmental initiatives.

The game takes place in eight turns, and each turn is divided in the following phases: Event, Investment, Technology Acquisition, Revenue, Government Taxes & Subsidies

Event: on the beginning of each turn a random event is drawn and affects all the players.
Investment: Each player may buy a company of their choice (each company have in their tile the company cost, the revenue per turn, the emission level and how many green points it's worth)
Technology: technologies that improve the revenue points or reduce emissions may be bought by the players though auctions.
Revenue: Each player collect the revenue of their companies.
Taxes & Subsidies: Each player pays the taxes due or collects the subsidies if eligible to.


At the end of the 8th round the player with most green points wins the game.

Home Page: http://www.riachuelogames.com.br/economia/ (Portuguese)

boardgame.name: La Grande Boucle
boardgame.description:
From the Downey Games website:

La Grande Boucle (The Big Loop) is the nickname given to France’s biggest sporting event, the Tour de France.
Year in, year out, the route followed by the riders for 3 weeks broadly follows a loop around the country, hence the name of our game.

La Grande Boucle has been a labor of love for designer, Phil Riviere, for many years. Phil had released versions prior to partnering with Downey Games that were "highlight based" games. The Downey Games release of La Grande Boucle is a departure from previous designs. Rather than continuing the "highlight based" game engine, Phil has developed a full-blown simulation of the Tour de France.

Phil recently commented, " Although sharing the same name as previous versions, the latest incarnation is a completely different concept. No highlights here as the game system covers the action on the full length of each stage. Every single aspect of Road Racing is covered. There are also options for tactical choices."

La Grande Boucle is the ONLY full simulation of the Tour de France. Every stage, time trial, and rider is included in the game.

In game terms, the Tour de France is quite challenging a subject because of, the huge quantity of riders taking part (around 200) and the difference in the character of the 20 + stages which form the race. However, Phil has risen to the challenge. La Grande Boucle not only gives accurate results, but you'll feel as if you are taking part in the actual Tour de France.

We do want to reiterate that this is not simply a relabeling of an old game. La Grande Boucle version 4 is a completely new design.

Phil asked me to close with the following: "The game is meant to be played over several sessions. This is definitely not a fast or quick replay game. The flat stages are fairly quick to replay and will be slotted in one seating. Mountain stages, however, will take much longer to complete.

Not wishing to discourage you, but finishing this replay will be like finishing the Tour: Difficult but Rewarding. Be warned and enjoy the racing."

The game ships with the ratings for the 2004 Tour de France.

The printed game features individual, die-cut cards for all 189 riders; charts printed in full color, a complete rule book, Team lists in full-color, Replay data in full-color, dice, and a sturdy game box.

Note: The game is also available in a e-book version (print and play) for a lower price.

boardgame.name: The Battle of Algiers
boardgame.description:
"The Battle of Algiers" - Terrorism versus Torture

The game has two players. One plays the FLN and the other the paratroopers. The winner is the player who ends the game with the more political points.

The map represents Algiers in 1960 (three years after the battle of Algiers)
It is divided into 7 zones, each zone divided into 3 areas.

FLN players have 40 counters. Each counter represents a FLN cell with a value. This value is the level of the cell: I for the simplest FLN Activists, II for the FLN Cell Members, III for the FLN Leftenents, IV for the FLN Chiefs and V for the FLN Leaders.
FLN players has 15 level I counters, 12 level II, 7 level III, 5 level IV and one level V.

The Para player has 6 counters of different colours, one for each regiment engaged in the Battle of Algiers.
He also has 6 CC counter for the Commandments Centers.

Op zoek naar de gouden cacaoboon met Côte d'Or
boardgame.description:
A promotional game from chocolate factory Côte d'Or. The mechanics are based on the Game of Goose.

The players try to be the first to reach the golden cacao bean. They do this by rolling the dice and having a lot of luck.

When it is your turn you roll the dice and move your pawn based on your roll towards the golden bean. When you land on a green or red field you take an adventure card. When you land on a blue field you will move backwards in your next turn and when you land on a yellow field you can take a risk. You may roll again and when the result is a 1 or 2 you can move on to the number 28, but when you roll a 3,4,5 or 6 you have to move backwards 3,4,5 or 6 places.

Contents:
game board
pawns in different colors
one die
adventure cards

boardgame.name: Guerres secrètes
Les Super Héros Marvel: Guerres secrètes
boardgame.description:
The goal of the game is to put all your 5 pawns onto the board, avoiding all the traps your opponents set.
Each player chooses the character of his pawns (Kang, doctor Octopus, Magneto, doc Fatalis) and get 5 identical pawns with a drawing of this character. At the beginning of the game all players must be upon the same secret base (red or blue): they choose their places upon their secret cards. Pawns are moved accordingly to the result of the two dices in any direction. Any time a pawn reaches his secret base, his owner surrounds a new square on his secret card. But if he crosses a square surrounded by one of his opponents, he falls into a trap and must go back to his base, while the trapper(s) puts one of his tokens upon this square, and chooses another trapped square.

boardgame.name: Making Plays
boardgame.description:
“2 player card game. Simulation of an American Football game ... As in regular football, the player with the most points at the end of the game wins.”

The game uses a custom deck of cards made up of seven types of cards: Run, Pass, Kick, Blitz, Offense, Defense, and Special. Cards are played to gain Field Position Tokens which represent the offensive player’s position on the field, from the player’s goal line (zero tokens), to midfield (three tokens), to a touchdown (seven tokens). Down Tokens are used to track change of possession on downs, which occurs after the Offensive Player accumulates five of the tokens. Whenever the Offensive Player gains a Field Position Token, all but one of the Down Tokens are discarded.

Each player begins with a hand of five cards, and draws three cards at the start of each turn. The Offensive Player declares whether there will be a regular play, punt, or field goal attempt. The Defensive Player may play a Blitz Card. If the Blitz Card cannot be countered by the Offensive Player, the play is over. If a regular play was declared, the Offensive Player then declares either a running play or a pass play, and plays either a Pass or Run Card. If the card is not countered by the Defensive Player, the Offensive Player can play one additional card to increase the yardage of the play. A Run Card can be used to extend either type of play, but a Pass Card can only be used to extend a Pass play.

When an Offensive Player accumulates seven or more Field Position Tokens, a touchdown is scored and the Offensive Player receives six points. The point after touchdown attempt is governed by a die roll, as are punts, field goals, and kick offs.

boardgame.name: Lepanto
boardgame.description:
“Card game for 2 players. Simulation of the Naval Battle of Lepanto 1571. Ottoman Turks vs The Holy League.”

The game uses a custom deck of cards composed of Leader, Ship, Attack, Movement, and Scout cards. Each card has a Force value. Each turn the players fight a battle by revealing a set of cards which may consist of up to one Leader, four Ships, two Attack Cards, and two Movement Cards. The player with the higher total Force value wins the hand. Both players lose Strength Points equal to the total Force of the opponent’s cards. In addition, the loser of the hand also loses Strength Points equal to the difference between the two Force totals.

Each player starts with 100 Strength Points. A player wins by having twice as many Strength Points as the opposing player at the end of a turn.

boardgame.name: Clue: Harry Potter
Clue: Harry Potter Edition
Cluedo: édition Harry Potter
Cluedo: Harry Potter
Cluedo: Harry Potter Editie
Cluedo: Harry Potter Edition
boardgame.description:
From the Manufacturer
Discover the secrets of Hogwarts in this version of the classic Mystery game. Enjoy new game play features and a moving Hogwarts game board. Dark magic has been performed at Hogwarts. A fellow student has vanished from the famous School of Witchcraft and Wizardry--and it is up to you to solve the mysterious disappearance.
Play as Harry, Ron, Hermione, Ginny, Luna or Neville and try to discover who did it, what spell or item they used, and where the student was attacked. Was it Draco Malfoy with a Sleeping Draught in the Owlery?
Move around Hogwarts making suggestions--but watch out. Wheels on the board actually move to reveal secret passages, hidden staircases, and even the Dark Mark. Think you've gathered all the facts you need? Go to Dumbledore's office to make your final accusation to win the game.

This version of the classic Clue game combines the standard clue idea of going from room to room making suggestions of who, what, and where. However, this version adds a few new ideas. The first is the ever changing board. On a players turn s/he roles three dice, two regular and a special die. The special die has the four houses of Hogwarts on it. This allows a player to change the layout of the board, by opening/closing doors, changing the secret passage way, reveling the dark mark (causing lose of house points), or getting help cards.

The house points are a second change. In this version either a player can win, or all players can lose and the dark side wins, by getting all the players house points. House points are lost when the dark mark appears and a card is reveled from the dark deck. The players affected must either show a help card that protects them from the dark deck card, or lose the set number of house points. Dropping to zero house points causes a player to lose and out of the game.

The other two card types are the third change in the game. There are help cards that consist of items, allies, and spells. These are used to combat the second deck, the Dark Deck. The dark deck cards are revealed when a dark mark appears either on the dice roll, or by moving the house wheels changing the door layouts. The dark mark card affect players in specific locations and those players must be able to show the indicated help cards or lose house points.

All-in-all the idea is the same as traditional clue, but the extra things makes the game just different enough. People that like Clue and/or Harry Potter would enjoy this version.

boardgame.name: Interstellar Pig
boardgame.description:
"Card & Board game for 2-4 players. Find the Interstellar Pig or your entire race is doomed. This game is based on an imaginary game of the same name described in a novel of the same name written by William Sleator."

Each player starts with a character, four planets, and a random set of Attribute cards. The players travel from planet to planet collecting additional Attribute cards. If you kill an opposing player, you take all of that player's Attribute cards and the player is eliminated from the game.

The game lasts sixteen rounds. The player holding the Interstellar Pig Attribute card at the end of the game wins.

boardgame.name: Mexico City Campaign
boardgame.description:
Mexico City Campaign is a two player board game simulating the last month of fighting in the Mexican-American war (1846-1847) covering the period from mid-August to mid-September 1847. Following the invasion of Mexico that had started a year before in the north, US General Winfield Scott and his army arrived from Puebla in the eastern side of Mexico City to a village called Ayotla.

In Mexico City campaign one player takes control of the US army under the command of General Scott, and the other player takes control of the Mexican Army under the command of General Santa Anna, and each player moves his provided counters in an attempt to fulfill victory conditions as set out further below. The game commences on 12th August 1847 following the US arrival and finishes on 13th September 1847 unless the automatic victory conditions are fulfilled by either player.

This conflict simulation comes with the following components:
• Simulation Map
• Counters: Combat Units, Non-Combat Units and Mark Counters.
• Game Rules

Additionally players will need a 6 sided dice for combat resolution.

boardgame.name: TravFuda
boardgame.description:
Retheme and redesign of Hanafuda.
10 suits of 6 cards, with Traveller inspired artwork.

play is derivative from Hana-awase and Koi-Koi.

Mechanics of play: play one card from hand, and one card from top of deck to tableau; if a card played is matched by suit, stack on top of match. Pick up any stacks with even numbers of matched tiles.

Scoring is by set collection. Sets are themed.

boardgame.name: Death Ride of the Panzers
boardgame.description:
Death Ride of the Panzers - The German Attack on the Southern Shoulder of the Kursk Salient

Death Ride of the Panzers is a board game simulating the operations conducted by 4th Panzer Army and Army Detachment Kempf as part of Operation Citadel these formations were to form the southern pincer of the German assault. Operation Citadel was an attempt by the Germans to eliminate the Kursk Salient on the Eastern Front thus shortening the front line that needed to be held. As well as the hope of being able to destroy a large amount of Red Army forces thus dissipating their ability to conduct offensive operations in the coming winter. The battle simulated took place from the 5th July to the 13th July 1943.

The game consists of a map, 124 counters (1 turn counter, 48 German ground and air unit counters and the soviets have a total of 75 ground and air unit counters), 2 dice and a rule document.

boardgame.name: Byzanz
boardgame.description:
You are a merchant in Byzantium and you are trying to have the most profit from the markets inside the city.
Bid for the best stock of goods and find the right moment to sell your collected wares.
And do not forget to go to the main market for a good deal!

Players are merchants and bid on offers from the market to collect as many sets of 3 cards of the same good. Game ends when all cards have been auctioned and clayers with the highest total of good cards wins. Cards are both: money on your hand for bidding and points for scoring in each set sold.

Goods cards and merchant cards are shuffled together and form the stack of goods to be auctioned. Depending on number of players offer cards from 1 to 6 are used (eg 4 players, cards 2,3,4,5) with the highest card on top. The highest offer card is used to draw that number of goods to make the actual offer on the table. Players start with 4 goods cards in their hand as money for bidding. Players bid in clockwise order increasing their bid at least by 1 - or they pass. Last player with a bid will win the total offer. The bidding cards (= good cards from the players hand) will be placed face up and sorted by kind into the market. Also one of the cards of the offer he won has to be paid as "tax" to the market also- players choice. Than he takes all the other cards of the offer into his hand and he also places the offer card of the actual bid in front of him. He is not allowed to bid again in this round.

Game goes on with the next highest offer card giving the number of goods making the new offer. So each round each player win different a decreasing number of good cards. When all offers are gone the open market is usually filled with goods. Than the player with the lowest offer card - the same player who won the most less good cards - has free choice to take all cards of one kind from the goods in the market. Often this is a really great grab!

Following rounds are played the same way until all goods have been auctioned. Players can also sell sets consisting of exactly 3 cards of the same good from their hands whenever they want. That is no real sale but players hold the highest card of each set for scoring. Merchant cards can be used as a joker - even two merchants are allowed in a set of 3 goods. Although merchant cards have a value of 0, a set of 3 merchants will score 5 points!

96 cards with 6 different goods (eg cloth, wine, spice)
- each good with values 1 (6x), 2 (5x,) 3 (3x), and 4 (2x)
16 merchant cards value 0 but replacing any card you want in a set
6 offer cards (from 1 to 6) showing the number of cards to be auctioned
2 market cards where to place cards spend for bidding and "tax" cards

Note that all details for this game are preliminary. This game has not been released, and since its announced release date has long since passed, this game might never be released. This listing serves as a historical record; you are invited to submit corrections or update this section if additional information comes to light.




Players each play as a unique character from one of the house factions in George R. R. Martin's Westeros universe.

This is an adventure style game where players use a set number of actions per turn to travel, fight, play cards, and rest.

This game is card-driven and the cards allow you to gain items, allies, and stats, as well as attack and hinder your opponents. Many of the cards have conditions which, when successfully met, give you points in three different categories.

The game is divided into three "acts". At the end of Act III, whoever has the highest score in their weakest category wins the game.

This game was first shown at Gencon 2008 where it was available for public playtesting. It was in unpublished prototype form at that time.

boardgame.name: Bear & Bull
boardgame.description:
The game has been developed by Identity Games in Rotterdam for Robeco as a promotional game.

The goal of the game is to accumulate several victory points. Points are scored in several ways:
1. By investing a full 100% (in steps of 25%) in a economic sector.
2. With special strategy cards worth 1 point. When you land on a strategy field you can pick up 1 card.
3. By investing in different areas at the same time around the world.
4. By investing in all sectors at the same time (regardless of area)

The game shares several similarities with Monopoly, like roll-and-move, buying assets, completing sets, drawing cards when landed on certain fields on the board. There are also some differences, for example you can takeover someone's assets when you land on his field and he has no full set yet.

boardgame.name: Ben 10 Yo!
Dino's Yo!
Yo! Marvel Heroes
boardgame.description:
A fun game of bluff for 2-4 players Ages 7 and up, using 33 fact-filled cards on Marvel Super Heroes.

The game play is similar to a card-based version of Perudo. Each player selects a number of cards from their hand, passes to the player on the left and announces e.g. "3 Blue". The receiving player can then accept the statement as truth and take the cards or challenge it as a bluff. If they're right, the active player has to reduce their score by the announced value. If they're right, they must reduce their score. First one to lose 15 points is the loser. Bids must increase until a challenge is made.

The game box has an integrated scoring track.

There are several other versions of this game. The first set consists of Marvel Heroes, Ben 10, Baby Animals, Horses, Monster Jam, and Dinos. Other than the card art the games appear to be identical.

boardgame.name: Przygody w dżungli
boardgame.description:
Old Polish game. Each player becomes an explorer in the tropical jungle. Pawns can move only in straight lines, you cannot jump over another pawns or "dangers of the jungle". However, the amount of fields covered in one move is not limited. After finishing a movement player picks up one adjacent tile. It can be:

- a desired object or animal, helpful in explorations (elephant for example)
- object scoring VP
- "danger of the jungle"

One player is not a usual explorer. Instead he plays the role of the "jungle". He aims to trap the players (by guarding the exits). When a "danger" tile is discovered, it enters the maze and "jungle" player is able to move it from this moment.

In any moment players acting as "explorers" may exit the jungle. They count VP on gathered tiles. At the end of the game (when everybody left the jungle or is not able to do it). The player acting as "jungle" earns VP for:

- every tile, that has not been discovered
- every VP tile gathered by trapped players, who did not leave the jungle.

Player with the most VP is the winner.

boardgame.name: Turning the Tide
boardgame.description:
Turning the Tide - The Battle of Bemis Heights (October 7, 1777)

The Battle of Bemis Heights (October 7, 1777) is a two player simulation of the second Battle of Saratoga in the American Revolutionary War. Although conflicts between the Americans and the British occurred throughout the day of October 7, this simulation’s focus is over the skirmish at Barber’s Wheatfield. For the purposes of this game, a hexagonal grid map is provided and used to regulate movement and combat. The game map is presented in a standard North-South format. The map covers an area approximately 1650 yards wide and 900 yards high, and thus each hex is representative of approximately 66 yards. The game has six turns which represent intervals of ten minutes. A series of counters are also provided representing particular units for both the British and American forces.

boardgame.name: The Battle of Brunete
boardgame.description:
The Battle of Brunete (Spanish Civil War)
5 – 25th OF JULY 1937

The Brunete Campaign was the first Republican offensive in the Spanish Civil War after the failure of the Nationalist forces to conquer Madrid. An attack in the Brunete area, west of Madrid, was intended to relieve the capital from its siege under the Nationalists. However the campaign turned out to be a debacle with little success after initial breakthrough.
The Battle of Brunete is a war game system simulating the Brunete battle, which was one of the crucial battles between the Nationalist and Republican forces in the Spanish Civil War. The Battle of Brunete simulation was designed for two players, one controlling the Republican units, representing the Loyalists, Anarchists, Communists, Liberals, and various International Brigades which were supported by the Soviet Union and the other player controlling the Nationalists, mainly Franco’s army, supported by German and Italian Fascists.

The game set consists of one “17 x 22” inch map sheet and one counter sheet of 90 counters (units and markers). Additionally players will need a 6 sided die for combat resolution.

TPOC: The Politics of Cannibals
boardgame.description:
Welcome to the cannibal village of Tpoc!

Disaster befalls the village when the latest chief of the village has died! Play the role of an ambitious young cannibal who wants to become the next chieftain by finding out the issues that are the most important to the members of the tribe. You need to both convince the majority that you have their best interests in mind, and serve those who support your rivals at your next meal. Once all the villagers who will be on the tribal counsel are identified, they will hold a vote for the next chieftain of Tpoc. Finally you will learn if the villagers will raise you to the position you deserve.., or if you have fallen out of favor, and into flavor!

TPOC (The Politics of Cannibals) is a card and tile driven game for 3 - 5 players. You will play cards from your hand to the table before you to show your political "Platform." As the game progresses, tiles will be drawn from a bag to indicate how certain members of the tribe feel on one of 6 different issues such as (Religion, Farming, Labor, Trade, Cultural Identity, and Warfare.) Does a villager dare to challenge you? throw them into the POT! Each player must also be aware that at any time, one of the leaders of these six areas may decide to endorse the strongest candidate in their given area.
At game end, the player whose platform cards best match the tiles in play wins the game.

boardgame.name: Reich of the Dead
boardgame.description:
The time is January 27th 1945.

Allied Command HQ
Excerpts from the Wolf Group Briefing
Without cause the Germans winter offensive through the Ardennes Forrest has abruptly come to a halt. Along the entire front, hordes of refugees have flooded into Allied camps all telling the tales of the dead coming back to life. Something has gone horribly wrong and zombie German Army humanoids, known as Kroids, are attacking with organized military efficiency.

- Who is leading the Kroids?
At this time we have no idea who, or what, is controlling or leading these Kroid forces. Reports have led to speculation that the leader of the Kroids is a summoned demon that was resurrected or awakened by the experiments of the SS Project Diabolus team at Castle Wewelsburg in Germany.

- Where do the Kroids come from?
All we know at the moment is that they are the reanimated remains of fallen soldiers or zombies – but not the mindless zombies seen in the Dracula movies we watched in the theaters as kids. Instead, these zombies appear to independently think and communicate. As they attack and kill our troops their ranks grow in numbers. What we do know is that a dead soldier, in any condition, burned, missing limbs or shot all to hell will, if not 'finished,' rise as a Kroid within 24 hours. A 'finished' corpse is one that has had its head removed.

- Why are the Kroids here and what do they want?
Sadly we have no idea. We believe this is the result of same wacky Nazi secret weapon experiment gone horribly wrong and we will just have to deal with it as best as we can. We do know that a Nazi machine called the Cyclomatron was built and activated by a team of SS scientists and engineers working at Castle Wewelsburg in Germany. Somehow this machine is the power behind these Kroids.

- How do we defeat the Kroids?
To date our strategy has been one of attacking the Third Reich's ability to wage war. We have been very successful in dismantling their infrastructure by destroying factories, refineries and transport. We have denied them the ability to manufacture and deploy the tools of war. The Kroids have no supply lines and they pick their tools of war up off the ground. They do not need to eat; they do not need to sleep. Their machines do not run on gas and ball bearings. Simply put, we have to change our entire strategy. As commanders you must think with your head. A casualty in your command is a new recruit for the Kroid army. The orders you have already received detail our current strategy, which is one of containment. Until further notice we are going on the defensive.

boardgame.name: Snow Tails
boardgame.description:
Snow Tails is set in the snowy world of the Arctic Circle, where brave sledders compete in a test of skill and endurance. Action is fast and furious and not all sleds may make it to the finish. Huskies only have one setting and that is full speed! Hang on to your furs, the reins, your sled and anything else you can get hold of.

The game contains modular track pieces which can be fitted together to form different courses. Players have their own Dog Decks which they draw from and play onto their sled mat. Movement is rarely in a straight line as the sled may drift left or right. Losing control or speeding into a corner results in Dent cards being acquired which will limit a player's hand size.

The game features a fun and original movement mechanism.


Game Summary
Race courses are built randomly. Players each have a dog sled with 2 dogs (initially valued 3 each) and a brake (also 3). Each player has the same deck of cards (5 sets of cards 1-5, shuffled) from which they draw a hand of 5 cards.

On your turn, may play 1-3 cards of the same value to these 3 locations (dog1, dog2, brakes). Forward speed (and distance moved) = dog1 + dog2 - brake + bonus (=position in race) if (dog1 = dog2). Lateral movement distance = dog1 - dog2 (move to the side with the stronger dog). Certain parts of the track have speed limits; you take damage if you exceed them, or if you run into obstacles (ice patches, side of track, etc.). Damage = cards that take up space in your hand (so 5th damage --> out of the race!).

The first player to cross the finish line wins!

boardgame.description:
Sudden Full Contact - The Battle of the Bulge 1944 is a detailed new VARIANT Historical Module that tells the story of the Battle of the Bulge and the struggle for the critical village of Hotton, which lays astride the Ourthe River crossing. The gamer is transported into a pitched battle, with German attackers hurling tanks and men against the American defenders in a desperate attempt to ward off the defeat of the Third Reich. Standing in their way are resourceful Yank engineers and tank-men with no intention of taking one step back. This is not a complete game. Ownership of Beyond Valor: ASL Module 1 and Yanks: ASL Module 3 are needed to play this game.

The entire battle-site was mapped on foot by designer Pedro Ramis and the detail is incredible! Scenarios bring you into the ranks of the 23rd Armored Engineer Battalion, Kampfgruppe Bayer, Task Force Mize, CCR, and other hard-fighting combat elements.

The games comes with new historical game map and 8 scenarios.

boardgame.name: Devils in the Woods: The Battle of the Bulge 1944
boardgame.description:
Devils in the Woods—The Battle of the Bulge 1944 is a new scenario pack that tells the story of the Battle of the Bulge from the perspective of the dog faces of the American 3rd Armored Division, facing down an onrushing German 116th Panzer Division during 20-24 December, 1944. The gamer is hurled into the height of the most dangerous period of the Battle of the Bulge, in pitched battles that play out over two historical maps, covering Melines and the Quatre Bras crossroads portions of the battlefield.

The game is an Advanced Squad Leader module.

The entire battle-site was mapped on foot by designer Pedro Ramis and the detail is incredible! Scenarios bring you into the ranks of the 23rd Armored Engineer Battalion, Kampfgruppe Bayer, Task Force Mize, CCR, and other hard-fighting combat elements.

The game comes with two historical game maps and 12 scenarios. The scenarios are numbered #9-#20.

listing.notes:
ASL CH Historical pack "Devils in the woods"
The module published by Critical Hit and designed by Pedro Ramis/David Lamb focuses on the battle of the Bulge and more precisely the actions near the town of Hotton.
The pack contains: 1 historical map "Quatre bras" related to the defended crossroad of the same name 1 second historical map "Melines" that depicts this hamlet 12 scenarios (8 on Quatre-bras, 4 on Melines map) of rather small-size kind and quite fun to play. 1 sheet of special rules applicable on all the scenarios A cardboard strengthener
Shipping charge is EUR 10,50 for DE, UK, SP, IT, NL, BE, LU, PT, AT with tracking service. Possible shipping to a pick-up store: France 5 EUR, Spain, Belgium, Netherlands and Luxembourg 7.50 EUR. boardgame.name: Nations at War
boardgame.description:
"2-5 player card game with WWII theme." The players represent the Axis (Germany, Japan) and Allied (Britain, Russia, America) forces.

Each nation has a custom deck of cards, which represent various sea, land, and air units used by the nation. The cards are divided into four categories: Action, Leader, Permanent, and Modifier.

Leader Cards and Permanent Cards represent improvements or advantages that provide various bonuses to the nation until the card is destroyed. Action Cards typically represent strategies, tactics, defenses, or events. They are played when appropriate and then discarded. Modifier Cards are bonuses that must be attached to a specific unit.

The object of the game is to reduce your opponents to zero Power Points. Each player starts with twenty-five Power Points.

"Card & Dice game for 2-4 players. Based on the Orkworld RPG by John Wick. Each player controls a Tribe (Gathum) of Orks." Solo play rules are also included.

"Use Metal or plastic figures to represent your Population. 1 Figure = 1 Ork."

The game also uses a custom deck of cards composed of nine types of cards: Foe, Weapon, Armor, Tribal Item, Personal Item, Personal Modifier, Tribal Modifier, Battle Event, and Non-Battle Event.

The players attempt to build their tribes into effective fighting forces in order to defeat Foe cards played on the tribes by other players. Defeating a Foe card increases a Tribe's Fame Points.

In addition to taking casualties in battle, other circumstances will affect the population of the players' tribes. Each turn a hunting roll is made to determine whether conditions will result in any increase or decrease in population.

"Victory: The first player to accumulate 25 Fana (Fame) points and survive is the winner."

boardgame.name: Pawn Poker
boardgame.description:
An abstract strategy game played on a large 5x5 grid. The game also requires a different colored pawn for each player and a standard deck of playing cards.

At the start of the game, the deck is shuffled and a card is placed on each of the twenty-five spaces on the board. The players then select their starting corners and place their pawns.

As the players take turns moving their pawns, they get to keep the card (if any) from the space that the pawn was moved from. The game ends when all of the cards have been collected.

The object of the game is to make the best five card Poker hand from the playing cards collected by the player.

boardgame.name: Prohibition
boardgame.description:
"Board and Dice Game. American Prohibition 1920’s Theme. Players are smugglers transporting Alcohol."

The games is played on a circular track containing three types of spaces - source, establishment, and culture. The players earn Bankrolls (money) by buying Cases (alcohol) from Sources and transporting it to Establishments. Each Culture space has two Bankrolls placed on it at the start of the game. boardgame.name: Space Opera
boardgame.description:
"Explore the mysteries of outer space with your trusty ship and intrepid crew."

The player is in command of a starship. The attributes of the starship and the skills of the crew are randomly determined by rolling on tables. The six member crew includes a captain, science officer, chief engineer, and three specialists (science, technical, or ship systems). The object of the game is to complete ten missions in the shortest time possible.

Missions are randomly generated by referring to tables. To complete a mission, the ship must face three random threats generated by rolling on tables. The crew and ship must have the skills and systems required by the threats and the mission to successfully complete the mission. If the player cannot complete the mission, the result is randomly determined by rolling on the failure table.

The game also includes three additional scenarios that expand on the basic game.

In the Drax Campaign scenario, the player must complete missions in order to win the war against the Drax. The player controls three starships. The attributes for these ships are generated by rolling on special wartime ship systems tables. Successfully completing missions makes a player victory more likely, while the failure to complete missions will lead to a Drax victory.

In the scenario A Long Way Home the starship must complete missions to reach a home destination. In the scenario A Campaign of Terror the starship must complete missions to defeat aliens threatening the human colonies.

boardgame.name: Bitwy II wojny światowej
boardgame.description:
Bitwy II wojny światowej (B-35) (Battles of World War II) is a system designed for representing World War II medium battles.

Counters represent battalions and companies, one hex represents about 2000m (depending on specific game), one turn represents 8, 12 or 24 hours.

B-35 has a high level of complexity. Rules include airborne/sea landings, fire combat (long distance combat between armoured units), air force, engineers, special units etc.
Another distinctive feature of this system is the way of determining strength of unit. Each unit has a chart with its strength; when unit suffers loses, player has to mark it on chart.
Classical activation system ("I go, you go") and simplified command rules drives the game.

The game contains fiction map and scenarios but historical units (German, American, Polish and British).

Bitwy II wojny światowej (B-35) debuted in 1993 in the 3rd issue of the Magia i Miecz magazine. Some small boards and counters, along with rules were published there in the Klan Miłośników Gier Strategicznych part of the magazine. Later system moved to the Strategia i Taktyka and Dragon magazines. Dragoncompany published first boxed edition of the system along with some other games using it (Szczury Pustyni, Kaserine 1943). Rules evolved and were published in the Dragon Hobby magazine in the 90's. In the same time additional rules for the Pacific War Theatre, along with the new boards, were published in the Dragon Hobby magazine as well.

After the end of the Dragon company, Taktyka i Strategia company took care of the system, publishing new editions (currently 4th), with new boards, scenarios and the games. As for now (2018) Bitwy II wojny światowej (B-35) is the most complex WW II Polish system with biggest number of games, scenarios and expansions, published frequenntly in the Taktyka i Strategia magazine.

Board's publication history:
Dania - Dragon Hobby 1/98
Drezno - Taktyka i Strategia 3/2002
Fiordy - Taktyka i Strategia 15/2005
Finlandia - Taktyka i Strategia 20/2006
Map nr. 5 - Taktyka i Strategia 31/2010

boardgame.name: Osmose
Osmosis
boardgame.description:
"Osmosis" was published in A Gamut of Games. A word from Sid Sackson:
"It would be difficult for me to say why, how, or even when I created the following work. Like the game itself, the ideas seemed to flow shapelessly around until, before I realized it, they had taken concrete shape.
"Osmosis is a subtle game. What constitutes a good hand? What constitutes a good play? The contestants must discover this for themselves, more by intuition than by logic"

Osmosis is played with a normal deck of cards, but without some cards according to the number of players. Each player starts with a eight card hand and to win a round he must gather more than 11 cards, when he scores alone or he loses when he reaches 4 cards, then all other players scores. Cards are gathered by trading with the other player is very specific ways.

boardgame.name: Muster
Patterns
boardgame.description:
"Patterns" was published in A Gamut of Games. A word by Sid Sackson:
"Patterns has many characteristics of a board game. All the cards are face up on the table, so there are no mysteries. Play is in moves, which are determined by the relationship of the cards to one another. Some players find the interplay of the "patterns" a fascinating challenge. Other never see it. To find out whether it is "your cup of tea" you'll have to try it."

Each player takes twelve cards from a normal deck of cards numbered from 1 to 13 (Ace to K). Then shuffles his cards and deals then in two lines of six cards each. The objective is, by moving two cards each turn, complete a pattern before the other player. The catch is that the moves you are allowed to make are based on your opponents' cards. If you do a difficult move, you win points, if you make an easy one you lose points. When you win a hand, you score the number of point you get that hand (can be zero).

boardgame.description:
"All my Diamonds" was published in A Gamut of Games, with this introduction from Sid Sackson:


"All my Diamonds is a game I conceive as a change of pace from Poker. Although there is no similarity in the play, it satisfies the same urge for speculation. It is, basically an auction game where players must decide whether they can earn more by buying or by selling"


All my Diamonds is played with a regular deck of cards with the "10" out, making 48 cards. Cards are divided in sets, with each card belonging a "value" set and also to a "suit" set, each set has 12 cards and players must set collections of 10 cards in any set to win a hand. Players exchange cards by auctioning all cards in a set in their hands.

The player with most points win in the end, this can be achieved by completing the sets, that once completed are exchanged for points, or by selling his cards on the auction.

boardgame.description:
"The King has vanished and the kingdom has plunged into chaos, heirs to the throne are divided, and invaders have landed on the shores, plundering the land. Choose a faction and rally your War Band to fight for glory and honor. Become a Rusted Hero today!"

Rusted Heroes 32mm Table-top Miniature Game is a fast playing skirmish style combat game system using d10s (1 to 10+) not percentage dice. The higher the roll the better in most cases. Each miniature represents a character on the battlefield. Since this is a skirmish based game each side will have any where from five or more miniatures in their War Band.

Each character has two actions per turn. With these two Actions a character can do several things on their turn. Some may include a standard move and attack, use both actions to make a run movement, attack an enemy model twice, attack once and reserve one for defense, open a door or portcullis, change weapons from a bow to a sword, etc...

boardgame.name: Pass the Buck
boardgame.description:
Pass the Buck is one of at least three in this company's series of nature themed "Cigar Box" games. Pass the Buck is themed around North American wildlife, in particular 15 different animals on the cards from eagle, dove, cardinal, buck, skunk, bear, etc. in beautifully engraved animal art.

Object: 4-10 players vie to be the last player holding 1 or more wooden nickels.

Components:
-Cigar Box decorated with a deer Buck and red scroll with game title all in 18th century style drawn art. Interestingly, game is sealed with a simulated "tax stamp" featuring the serial number and company logo.
-52 playing cards in 4 sets of 10 (each set features 10 different birds), and 12 special play cards (4 bear, 2 duck, 1 doe, 1 skunk) with variable special abilities.
-50 wooden nickels with company logo on one side, and game title and image of Buck on the other.

Game Play description:
Each player starts with 5 wooden nickels. The dealer deals each player 1 card. In turn, each player looks secretly at the card and decides whether to keep or trade with player on the left. A player is stuck with their choice (keep or trade) once completed. Since players want the lowest value card possible, this adds an element of risk assessment, as the player(s) with the highest value must pay a nickel into the pot. Last player standing with nickels, after others are bankrupt wins. Special play cards change order and value of play for more variability to play.

boardgame.name: Naughty & Nice
boardgame.description:
Naughty & Nice is a quick playing card game I made for a friend's 30th birthday. During the game you play cards on yourself and on other players to increase or decrease your Naughty and Nice ratings. The object of the game is to end with the highest Naughty and Nice ratings with the smallest difference between them.

There are also Shiny! cards. You can play Shiny! cards to take cards from other players. At the end of the game, each Shiny! card has a 50/50 chance of being worth points. If a Shiny! card is worth points, you can add it to your Naughty score or your Nice score.

Naughty & Nice is a game for two to four players. It uses a custom card deck and a single die. A four-player game takes about 30 minutes to play. While the gameplay is rather simple, the ever-so-slightly mature theme of the game makes Naughty & Nice appropriate for Ages 16 and up.

Ultimate Werewolf

boardgame.description:
Your quiet little 16th century village has suddenly become infested with some very unfriendly werewolves...can you and the other villagers find them before they devour everyone?

Ultimate Werewolf: Ultimate Edition is the ultimate party game for anywhere from 5 to 68 players of all ages. Each player has an agenda: as a villager, hunt down the werewolves; as a werewolf, convince the other villagers that you're innocent, while secretly dining on those same villagers each night. Dozens of special roles are available to help both the villagers and the werewolves achieve their goals while thwarting their opponents.

Contents More than 30 unique roles, 18 different scenarios to allow groups of all sizes and experience levels to quickly get up and running, a set of 80 fully illustrated cards, a moderator scorepad to keep track of games, and a comprehensive game guide with dozens of pages full of insights, tips and strategies. This set has everything you need for the best Ultimate Werewolf experience possible, whether you’re playing with a small circle of friends at home, a huge gathering of gamers in Ohio or as an engaging team building exercise at the office.

Ultimate Werewolf: Ultimate Edition Roles:
Apprentice Seer, Aura Seer, Bodyguard, Cupid, Diseased, Ghost, Hunter, Idiot, Lycan, Magician, Martyr, Mason (3), Mayor, Old Hag, Old Man, P.I., Pacifist, Priest, Prince, Seer (2: 1 male & 1 female), Spellcaster, Tough Guy, Troublemaker, Villager (20), Witch, Sorcerer, Minion, Werewolf (12), Wolf Cub, Cursed, Doppelganger, Drunk, Cult Leader, Hoodlum, Tanner, Teenage Werewolf, Lone Wolf, Vampire (6), Amulet of Protection, Moderator, Blank Cards (3)

Re-implements:

Werewolf
Ultimate Werewolf: Whitebox Edition


Differences between 2010 Edition and 2008 Edition:

Role cards now have ability text
Includes Ultimate Werewolf: Classic Movie Monsters
No Magician card
Only eight Werewolf cards (note that rulebook still says twelve)
Only two blank cards (note that rulebook still says three)
Vampires are valued at -7 (previously -8)


Differences between 2011 Edition and 2010 Edition:

Includes Ultimate Werewolf: Night Terrors instead of Ultimate Werewolf: Classic Movie Monsters


Differences between 2013 Edition and 2011 Edition:

Includes Ultimate Werewolf: Urban Legends instead of Ultimate Werewolf: Night Terrors

boardgame.name: War for Atlantis
boardgame.description:
"One player takes the side of the Atlanteans. The other player takes command of the combined Armies of the Five Foes of Atlantis."

The game is played on a hex map. The continent of Atlantism containing the main city of Atlantis, is at the center of the map, surrounded by water. A thin border of land around the outer edges of the map represents the homelands of the enemies: The Barbarians, Greeks, Egyptians, Africans, and Lemurians.

Each enemy has a unique set of forces. Units are rated for power and movement. Some units are amphibious, some cannot leave the water, and others may fly. Mage and Priest units have magic powers.

"Victory: The Atlanteans are victorious if they destroy their enemies completely. The Five Foes win if they destroy all the Atlanteans or a have a spellcaster cast the cataclysm spell in the Temple of Posideon. The Atlanteans win a minor victory if there is no winner after 20 turns."

boardgame.name: Third World
boardgame.description:
"Card game for 2+ players. Simulation of problems facing third world countries. Each player controls his own Third World country."

The deck includes six types of cards: Political Reforms, Economic Reforms, Ecological Reforms, Political Crises, Economic Crises, and Ecological Crises.

Each player has three statistics that are tracked during the game: Political Stability, Economic Stability, and Ecological Stability. Each category starts with a value of 20.

A value of zero or less in Political Stability represents Anarchy & Civil War. Zero or less in Economic Stability represents Economic Collapse, and zero or less in Ecological Stability represents an Ecological Disaster.

A player wins by achieving a score of 30 or more in all three categories.

These events and more occur during the thirteen phases of each turn: New Day Phase, Genius Phase, Healing Phase, Minion Phase, Invention Phase, Recruit Phase, Plot Phase, Spy Phase, Assassin Phase, Plot Phase, Intercept Phase, Track Phase, and Attack Phase.

The goal is to eliminate all of your opponent's major characters. The first player to do so after the fifth turn wins the game.

boardgame.name: Superman
boardgame.description:
“Card game for 2 or more players. Each player takes on the role of Superman on a similar but alternate parallel Earth. Players compete to see who captures the most powerful villains.”

The players attempt to play combinations of cards to capture Villains. A combination must include the Villain Card to be captured, together with up to two Weapon Cards and one Plot Card. These cards represent the total Villain Point Value. The player must then play a Superman card together with Power, Ally, and Equipment Cards having a higher total value than the Villain Point Value.

Opponents may then play Weapon and Plot Cards to aid the Villain. The player may then respond by playing additional Power, Ally, and Equipment Cards. If the total value of the Superman cards still exceeds the total Villain Point Value, the Villain is captured and placed in the players Prison Pile together with all Weapon and Plot Cards played to support the Villain.

The game ends after the last card is drawn from the deck. The winner is the player having a Prison Pile worth the most total points.

boardgame.name: Pantery w akcji (Kaniów 1943)
Pantery w akcji (Kaniów 1943)
Panthers in action (Kaniev 1943)
boardgame.description:
Pantery w akcji (Kaniów 1943) (Panthers in action - Kanev 1943) presents the situation in late 1943.

After the fall at Kursk, the German army was withdrawing to the West. The major obstacle for the Red Army was the Dniepr river, especially since south of Kiev only one bridge was left - the railway one near Kanev.
Expecting an attack of Kiev, the German forces were unprepared for a Soviet attack aimed at siezing the bridge. Combined Armoured Corps and airborne units soon threatened to have the German forces cut off from the Western bank of the river. The situation was to be rescued by reinforcements of 19th and 7th Panzer Divisions but they come to late - the Dniepr was taken by Red Army.

The game uses rules of the B35 (Battles of World War II 1943-1945) system designed for dealing with medium battles of World War II. Counters represent battalions (Germans) or regiments (Russians), one hex represents 1500m, one turn represents 12 hours.

boardgame.name: Herr der Ziegen
boardgame.description:
Players move around a 7x7 grid of many sets of goat cards, milk can cards, and herding dog cards, picking up one card each turn from the row their goat token lands next to.

Cards are spent from a hand of two cards, first as movement points to keep moving around the grid on a subsequent turn, and second as melds to try to collect 8 points from a set of five goat cards numbered 1-5.

Once 8 points is achieved, the remaining cards in that set of five cards are marked on the grid as belonging to that player, and those are the main victory points in the game. (There is a secondary way to score by collecting milk cans.) Players try to get the 8 points in several different sets as the game progresses.

Once a player has some goats on the grid, the herding dog cards become useful. They are played to move his cards on the grid into a player's home scoring area -- the original "pen of goats" square he starts the game with, or any square contiguous to this gradually expanding area -- where the points are doubled.
